posts.name: Jacob Callahan
posts.cooked: Working on getting our robot up and moving. Everything is wired (Rio, Rev PDP, Radio, Pneumatic system). Along with our 4 falcons as our drive motors. We have everything wired using CAN, and I’m running into issues with the phoenix tuner. I don’t believe there is anything wrong with the CAN wiring itself, we have re-done it many times. My phoenix tuner recognizes the Rio but never shows any of my can devices. Now my Falcons are orange as soon as they get power and then flash red fast. I believe this means my CAN is connected and there is some sort of fault with the Falcons. Does anyone know what this fault is? Or if there is something in the phoenix tuner I’m missing? I typically have problems with the phoenix tuner every year, but this year I haven’t had any success in recognizing devices.

posts.name: Fletch
posts.cooked: Have you changed the CAN IDs for each of the motor controllers? I assume you’re trying to do this via Phoenix Tuner.  Make sure you’re following the “bring up” guide here: Bring Up: CAN Bus — Phoenix documentation

link_counts.title: Bring Up: CAN Bus — Phoenix documentation

posts.name: NewtonCrosby
posts.cooked:
According to the Falcon500 user guide:

LEDs Alternate1 Off/Slow Red CAN / PWM is not detected LEDs Alternate1 Off/Fast Red Fault Detected LEDs Alternate1 Red / Orange Damaged Hardware LEDs Strobe “towards” (M+)2 Off/ Red Forward Limit Switch or Forward Soft Limit LEDs Strobe “towards” (M-)2 Off/ Red Reverse Limit Switch or Reverse Soft Limit

It would appear you have a fault detected in the hardware, nothing to do with Phoenix Tuner.

I would agree with Fletch in that you should bring them up one at a time.  It’s particularly precarious that you can see the Roborio but not the PDP .  I think your CAN wiring is probably incorrect.

posts.name: Jacob Callahan
posts.cooked:
Screenshot 2022-01-22 191958 1920×1080 216 KB We’ve confirmed connectivity of our can loop, with a multimeter. Our can loop currently only consist of the PDP, 1 motor, and the Rio. We still have no devices showing up in Phoenix Tuner

posts.name: snoman
posts.cooked: Assuming it is wired correctly (starting at the rio and to a motor and the next ending in the Rev PDH) I would be looking at the PDH maybe firmware? If you swap out the Rev with the old CTRE will it work? Just a guess…

posts.name: Fletch
posts.cooked:
Have you tried swapping out that one motor for a different motor? It’s possible that one is the problem, so best to rule it out.

Next step I’d probably take is swapping out the REV PDH for an older CTRE PDP just to rule that out.

Also, you mention testing the CAN wiring with a multimeter. Can you explain what process was used to test it? Perhaps the test process was flawed in some way.

posts.name: Brad
posts.cooked: We had issues bringing up Phoenix the first time with the PDH.  First check all your connections and blink codes then make sure you have some code deployed to the robot.  The 2022 version of phoenix can install a client but does not need it if you have a 2022 project installed. If all your wiring is good and you have code installed. Download the rev client.  Connect to the PDH through usb.   Flash the update to the PDH.  After that you might see the falcons as can devices in the Rev client.   Clear all the sticky faults.   After that you should be able to connect.  If not try shortening your can bus to one device and see if you can get it to work then, if so add devices 1 by 1 until you find the problem.

posts.name: Ryan
posts.cooked: We had a similar issue. We fixed it by making sure both the Phoenix tuner and the Phoenix framework were installed. Somehow, we skipped the second Phoenix install step.

posts.name: Allen Nuttle
posts.cooked:
Check that you have current version of Phoenix Tuner, and try manually running the diagnostic client (this can get around some of the issues others have mentioned with not having all the right bits on the RIO) (step 4 in this procedure ).

Checking for CAN connectivity using a multimeter (continuity) is not really the best approach.  You can measure the DC resistance to be sure you are seeing the termination resistor at each end (see tip # 1 here ).  But, continuity testing can sometimes be misleading, depending upon how exactly it is being done.

It is much better to use one of the vendor utilities to enumerate the devices.  If this isn’t happening with a single device (you probably don’t need termination resistors in this configuration, allowing you to simplify the wiring even further), there’s something going on that needs to be sorted out.  The suggestion to try the REV client as well, including via USB, is a good one.  At this point, you should be able to assign IDs and use the blink test to confirm things.

Send pictures of the CAN wiring if you are still having issues.

link_counts.title: Practical tips: CAN-Bus – KMP Drivetrain Solutions

posts.name: acastagna
posts.cooked: We fixed a connectivity issue by switching from a long 3 ft usb cable to a shorter one . The long one would let us deploy code but not connect to the tuner .
